item.title: Query Azure Policy Compliance results using KQL
item.description: Last blogpost I showed you an Azure Policy that checked for a SQL server firewall rule. The results would be a compliance view in Azure Policy. After the blogpost, me and Dennes Torres had a chat about the results you get in the compliance view. The problem: you don’t get the resource ID or resource name for the SQL server with the setting on. This isn’t really a problem if you have only one not-compliant resource, but if you have several, it becomes tedious.
